trans-unit.source: The FULL clause forces the user to enter data into the field it is specified on (or into all subordinate input-capable fields if specified on a group item) sufficient to fill every character position of the field.
The GENERATE statement presents data to a report.
The GLOBAL (see GLOBAL) option, if used, allows a declarative procedure to be used across the program containing the USE statement and any subprograms nested within that program.
The GLOBAL clause may only be specified at the 77 or 01 level.
The GOBACK statement is used to logically terminate an executing program.
The GROUP INDICATE clause specifies that the data item in whose definition the clause appears will be presented only in very limited circumstances.
The IDENTIFICATION DIVISION. header is always optional.

The IF statement is used to conditionally execute an imperative statement (see Imperative Statement) or to select one of two different imperative statements to execute based upon the TRUE/FALSE value of a conditional expression.
The INITIAL, COMMON and RECURSIVE words are used only within subprograms serving as subroutines. Their purposes are as follows:
The INITIALIZE statement initializes each identifier-1 with certain specific values, depending upon the options specified.
The INITIATE statement starts Report-Writer Control System (RWCS) processing for a report.
The INITIATE statement will initialize all of the following for each report named on the statement:

The INPUT-OUTPUT section provides for the definition of any files the program will be accessing as well as control of the I/O buffering process against those files through the FILE-CONTROL and I-O-CONTROL paragraphs, respectively.
The INSPECT statement is used to perform various counting and/or data-alteration operations against strings.

The INSPECT statement will make a single pass through the sequence of characters comprising the inspect subject. As the pointer to the current inspect target character reaches a point where it falls within the explicit or implicit target ranges specified on the operational instructions of the two clauses, the actions specified by those instructions will become eligible to be taken. As the character pointer reaches a point where it falls past the end of target ranges, the instructions belonging to those target ranges will become disabled.
The INTEGER function returns the greatest integer value that is less than or equal to number (a numeric literal or data item).
The IS mnemonic-name-1 syntax provides a means for setting the switch to either an ON or OFF value via the SET statement (see SET).
The LEFT and RIGHT (SYNCRONIZED) clauses are syntactically recognized but are otherwise non-functional.
The LEFTLINE (see LEFTLINE), OVERLINE (see OVERLINE) and UNDERLINE clauses may be used in any combination in a single field’s description.
The LEFTLINE (see LEFTLINE), OVERLINE and UNDERLINE (see UNDERLINE) clauses may be used in any combination in a single field’s description.
The LEFTLINE clause will introduce a vertical line at the left edge of a screen field.
The LEFTLINE, OVERLINE (see OVERLINE) and UNDERLINE (see UNDERLINE) clauses may be used in any combination in a single field’s description.
The LENGTH OF clause on a literal or identifier reference may generally be used anywhere a numeric literal might be specified, with the following exceptions:

The LENGTH-CHECK clause forces the user to enter data into the field it is specified on (or into all subordinate input-capable fields if specified on a group item) sufficient to fill every character position of the field.

The LENGTH clause will produce a numeric value for constant-name-1 identical to that which would be returned by the LENGTH intrinsic function executed against identifier-1 or a data item declared with a USAGE of usage-name.

The LINAGE clause may only be specified in the FD of a sequential or line sequential file. If used with a sequential file, the organization of that file will be implicitly changed to line sequential. The various components of the LINAGE clause define the layout of printed pages as follows:
The LINE ADVANCING device

The LINE and COLUMN clauses provide one mechanism for specifying the line and column position to which the cursor will be positioned before allowing the user to enter data. In the absence of one or the other, a value of 1 will be assumed for the one that is missing. The author’s personal preference, however, is to explicitly code both.
The LOCALE-COMPARE function returns a character indicating the result of comparing argument-1 and argument-2 using a culturally-preferred ordering defined by a locale.
The LOWLIGHT clause controls the intensity of text (FOREGROUND-COLOR) by setting that intensity to its lowest of three possible settings.
The MERGE statement merges the contents of two or more files that have each been pre-sorted on a set of specified identical keys.

The MIDRANGE (middle range) function returns a numeric value that is the arithmetic mean (average) of the values of the minimum and maximum numbers from the supplied list. Each number-n may be a numeric data items or a numeric literal.
The MOVE CORRESPONDING statement similarly-named items from one group item to another.
The MOVE statement will replace the contents of one or more receiving data items (identifier-2) with a new value — the one specified by literal-1 or identifier-1.
The MULTIPLE FILE TAPE clause is obsolete and is therefore recognized but not functional.
The MULTIPLY BY statement computes the product of one or more data items (identifier-2) and either a numeric literal or another data item.
The MULTIPLY GIVING statement computes the product of two literals and/or data items and saves that result in one or more other data items.
The NEXT GROUP option cannot be specified in either a REPORT HEADING or a PAGE HEADING.
The NEXT PAGE option cannot be used in a PAGE FOOTING.
The NO-ECHO (see NO-ECHO) and SECURE clauses are interchangeable, and may not be used together in the same data item description.
The NO-ECHO and SECURE (see SECURE) clauses are interchangeable, and may not be used together in the same data item description.
The NO-ECHO clause will cause all data entered into the field to appear on the screen as asterisks.
The NOT AT END clause is not allowed on either form of table search.
The NOT operator has the highest precedence of all logical operators, just as a unary minus sign (which “negates” a numeric value) is the highest precedence arithmetic operator.
The NOT option reverses the TRUE/FALSE value of the condition.
The NUMERIC class test considers only the characters ‘
The NUMVAL function converts a string (a group item, USAGE DISPLAY elementary item or alphanumeric literal) to its corresponding numeric value.
The OBJECT-COMPUTER paragraph is not allowed in a nested subprogram. A nested program inherits the OBJECT-COMPUTER settings of its parent program.
The OCCURS clause cannot be specified in a data description entry that has a level number of 01, 66, 77, or 88, although it is valid in data items described
The OCCURS clause is used to create a data structure called a table, where entries in that structure repeat multiple times.
The OCCURS clause may be used at the group level too, in which case the entire group structure repeats, as follows:
The OCCURS clause of table-name-1 must contain the following elements:

The OMITTED class condition is used when it is necessary for a subprogram to determine whether or not a particular argument was passed to it. In such class conditions, identifier-1 must be a linkage section item defined on the USING clause of the subprograms PROCEDURE DIVISION header. See PROCEDURE DIVISION USING, for additional information.
The OPEN statement makes one or more files described in your program available for use.
The ORGANIZATION of file-name-1 cannot be ORGANIZATION LINE SEQUENTIAL (see ORGANIZATION LINE SEQUENTIAL).
The OVERLINE clause will introduce a horizontal line at the top edge of a screen field.
The PADDING CHARACTER clause is syntactically recognized but is otherwise non-functional.
The PICTURE (see PICTURE) and/or USAGE (see USAGE) of the specified identifier-1 must be such as to define it as a numeric, unedited, preferably unsigned integer data item.
The PICTURE (see PICTURE) of the data item only contains A symbols.
The PICTURE (see PICTURE) of the report data item must be such that it would be legal to MOVE (see MOVE) the specified literal or identifier to a data item with that PICTURE.
The PICTURE of the data item contains nothing but the symbol 9 and at least one of the editing symbols $, +, -, CR, DB, ., ,, * or Z.
The PICTURE of the data item contains only X or a combination of A and 9 symbols plus at least one B, 0 (zero) or / symbol.
The PICTURE of the data item contains only X or a combination of A and 9 symbols.

The PICTURE of the report data item in who’s description this SUM clause appears in must be such that it would be legal to MOVE (see MOVE) the specified identifier-7 or literal-2 value to a data item with that PICTURE.

The PRESENT-VALUE function returns a value that approximates the present value of a series of future period-end amounts specified by the various value-n arguments at a discount rate specified by the rate argument.
The PREVIOUS option is available only for ORGANIZATION INDEXED files.
The PROCEDURE DIVISION of any GnuCOBOL program marks the point where all executable code is written.

The PROGRAM-ID and FUNCTION-ID paragraphs serve to identify the program to the external (i.e. operating system) environment. If there is no AS clause present, the program-id will serve as that external identification. If there is an AS clause specified, that specified literal will serve as the external identification. For the remainder of this document, that "external identification" will be referred to as the primary entry-point name.
The PROTECTED extended clause will effect the specified field to be limited in size, regardless of the picture size.2
The RANGE function returns a value that is equal to the value of the maximum number-n in the argument list minus the value of the minimum number-n argument.
The RD must be followed by at least one 01-level report group definition.
The READY TRACE statement turns procedure or procedure-and-statement tracing on.

The REDEFINES clause causes the data item in who’s definition the REDEFINES clause is specified (hereafter referred to as the redefines object) to occupy the same physical storage space as identifier-1 (hereafter referred to as the redefines subject).
The RELEASE statement adds a new record to a sort work file.
The RENAMES clause regroups previously defined items by specifying alternative, possibly overlapping, groupings of elementary data items.
The REPLACE statement provides a mechanism for changing all or part of one or more GnuCOBOL statements.
The REPLACING clause replaces one or more sub strings located in the inspect subject with a different, but equally-sized replacement sub string. If you need to replace a sub string with another of a

The REPORT SECTION (see REPORT SECTION) documentation explores the description of reports and the PROCEDURE DIVISION (see PROCEDURE DIVISION) chapter documents the various language statements that actually produce reports. Before reading these, you might find it helpful to read Report Writer Usage, which is dedicated to putting the pieces together for you.
The REPOSITORY paragraph is not allowed in a nested subprogram. A nested program inherits the REPOSITORY settings of its parent program.
The RESET TRACE statement turns procedure or procedure-and-statement tracing off.
The RETURN-CODE special register will not be updated (but any RETURNING or GIVING data item still will).
The RETURN statement is valid only within the OUTPUT PROCEDURE of a file-based SORT (see File-Based SORT) or a MERGE statement (see MERGE) statement.
The RETURN statement reads a record from a sort or merge work file.
The RETURNING clause is mandatory within a user-defined function, as all such must return a numeric result.
The RETURNING clause is optional within a subroutine, as not all subroutines return a value to their caller.

The REVERSE-VIDEO attribute swaps the specified or implied FOREGROUND-COLOR (see FOREGROUND-COLOR) and BACKGROUND-COLOR (see BACKGROUND-COLOR) attributes for the field whose definition contains this clause (or all subordinate fields if used on a group item).
The REWRITE statement replaces a logical record on a disk file.
The RH and REPORT HEADING terms are interchangeable, as are PH and PAGE HEADING, CH and CONTROL HEADING, DE and DETAIL, CF and CONTROL FOOTING, PF and PAGE FOOTING as well as RF and REPORT FOOTING.
The ROLLBACK statement has the same effect as if an UNLOCK statement (see UNLOCK) were executed against every open file in the program.

The ROUNDED option comes into play should the number of digits to the right of an actual or assumed decimal point be different between the specified literal or identifier value (the “source value”) and the PICTURE specified for the field in whose definition the SOURCE clause appears (the “target field”).
The SAME RECORD AREA clause allows you to specify that multiple files should share the same input and output memory buffers.
The SEARCH ALL statement performs a binary, or half-interval, search against a sorted table. This is generally
The SEARCH statement is used to sequentially search a table, stopping either once a specific value is located within the table or when the table has been completely searched.
The SELECT statement creates a definition of a file and links that COBOL definition to the external operating system environment.
The SET Condition Name statement provides one method of specifying the TRUE / FALSE value of a level-88 condition name.

The SET Program-Pointer statement allows you to retrieve the address of a procedure division code module — specifically the PROGRAM-ID, FUNCTION-ID or an entry-point established via the ENTRY statement (see ENTRY).
The SET ADDRESS statement can be used to work with the addresses of data items rather than their contents.
The SET ATTRIBUTE statement may be used to modify one or more attributes of a screen section data item at run-time.
The SET ENVIRONMENT statement provides a straight-forward means of setting environment values from within a program.
The SET LAST EXCEPTION statement will set the last program exception status to indicate no exception.
The SHARING and WITH LOCK clauses may not both be specified in the same OPEN statement.

The SIGN function returns a -1 if the value of number (a numeric literal or numeric data item) is negative, a zero if the value of number is exactly zero and a 1 if the value of number if greater than 0.
The SOURCE (see SOURCE), SUM (see SUM) and VALUE (see VALUE) clauses, valid only on an elementary item, are mutually-exclusive of each other.
The SPECIAL-NAMES paragraph is not allowed in a nested subprogram. A nested program inherits the SPECIAL-NAMES settings of its parent program.
The SPECIAL-NAMES paragraph provides a means for specifying various program and operating environment configuration options.
The SQRT function returns a numeric value that approximates the square root of number (a numeric data item or numeric literal with a non-negative value).

The START statement defines the logical starting point within a relative or indexed file for subsequent sequential read operations. It positions an internal logical record pointer to a particular record in the file, but does not actually transfer any of that record’s data into the record buffer.
The STDCALL convention will not be used.
The STDCALL convention, required to use the Microsoft Win32 API, will be used.
The STOP statement suspends program execution. Some options will allow program execution to resume while others return control to the operating system.
The STRING statement is used to concatenate all or a part of one or more strings together, forming a new string.

The STRING statement’s processing is based upon a current character pointer. The initial value of the current character pointer will be the value of identifier-4 at the time the STRING statement began execution. If no POINTER clause is coded, a value of 1 (meaning “the 1st character position”) will be assumed for the current character pointer’s initial value.
The SUBSTITUTE-CASE function operates the same as the SUBSTITUTE (see SUBSTITUTE) function, except that from-n string matching is performed without regard to case.
The SUBTRACT CORRESPONDING statement generates code equivalent to individual SUBTRACT FROM statements for corresponding matches of data items found subordinate to the two identifiers.

The SUBTRACT GIVING statement generates the arithmetic sum of all arguments that appear before the FROM (identifier-1 or literal-1), subtracts that sum from the contents of identifier-2 and then replaces the contents of the identifiers listed after the GIVING (identifier-3) with that result.
The SUM clause establishes a summation counter whose value will be arithmetically calculated whenever the field is presented.
The SUM clause may only appear in a CONTROL FOOTING report group.
The SUM function returns a value that is the sum of number-n arguments (these may be numeric data items or numeric literals).
The SUPPRESS statement causes the presentation of a report group to be suppressed.
The TALLYING clause counts the number of occurrences of one or more strings of characters in the inspect subject.
The TERMINATE statement causes the processing of the specified report(s) to be completed.

The TERMINATE statement will present each CONTROL FOOTING (if any), in reverse sequence of the control hierarchy, starting with the most minor up to FINAL (if any). During the presentation of these groups and the processing of any USE BEFORE REPORTING procedures for those groups, the prior set of control data item values will be available, as though a control break had been detected at the most major control data name.

The TEST-NUMVAL function evaluates string (a group item, USAGE DISPLAY elementary item or alphanumeric literal) for being appropriate for use as the string argument to a NUMVAL (see NUMVAL) function, returning to a integer a zero value if it is appropriate otherwise if one or more characters are in error, the position of the first character in error or the length of the field plus one for other cases such as all spaces.

The TIMES option will repeat the execution of the code within the perform scope a fixed number of times. When the PERFORM statement begins execution, an internal repeat counter (not accessible to the programmer) will be set to the value of literal-1 or the value within identifier-1.
The TO clause is used to define a data-entry field with no initial value; when a value is entered, it will be saved to the specified identifier.
The TRANSFORM statement scans a data item performing a series of mono-alphabetic substitutions, defined by the arguments before and after the TO clause.
The TRANSFORM statement will replace characters within identifier-1 that are found in the string specified
The TYPE (see TYPE) clause specifies the type of report group being defined.

The Tab and Back-Tab (Shift-Tab on most keyboards) keys will position the cursor from field to field in the line/column sequence in which the fields occur on the screen at execution time, regardless of the sequence in which they were defined in the screen section.
The UNDERLINE clause will introduce a horizontal line at the bottom edge of a screen field.
The UNSTRING statement parses a string, extracting any number of sub strings from it.
The UNSTRING statement’s processing is based upon a
The UNTIL conditional-expression-1 option will repeat the code within the perform scope until the specified conditional expression evaluates to a TRUE value.
The USAGE (see USAGE) of identifier-1 must be INDEX, POINTER or PROGRAM-POINTER.
The USAGE (see USAGE) of program-pointer-1 must be PROGRAM-POINTER.
The USAGE clause defines the format that will be used to store the value of a data item.
The USAGE specifications FLOAT-DECIMAL-16 and FLOAT-DECIMAL-34 will encode data using IEEE 754
The USAGE specifications FLOAT-LONG and FLOAT-SHORT use the IEEE 754
The USING clause defines the arguments that will be passed to a GnuCOBOL program which is serving as a subprogram.
The VALUE clause is ignored on EXTERNAL (see EXTERNAL) data items or on any data items defines as subordinate to an EXTERNAL data item.
The VALUE clause is used to define condition names or to assign values (at compilation time) to data items.

The VARYING clause, available on both formats of the PERFORM statement, is a looping mechanism that allows for the specification of one or more numeric data items that will be initialized to a programmer-specified value and automatically incremented by another programmer-specified value after each loop iteration.
The WHEN OTHER clause’s imperative-statement-other will be executed, if such a clause was coded.
The WHEN-COMPILED intrinsic function, not to be confused with the WHEN-COMPILED (see Special Registers) special register, returns the date and time the program was compiled, in ASCII.

The WITH FILLER, REPLACING and DEFAULT clauses are meaningful only if identifier-1 is a group item. They are accepted if it’s an elementary item, but will serve no purpose. The VALUE clause is meaningful in both cases.
The WITH [ NO ] LOCK option is the only one available to REWRITE or WRITE statements.
The WRITE statement writes a new record to an open file.
The X"E5" routine will sound the PC “bell”. There are no arguments and no returned value.
The longoptions are defined as a table of records with oname, has-value, valpoint and val.5
The shortoptions are written down as an alphanumeric field (i.e., a string with arbitrary size) as follows:
The Selection-Object is ANY
The access-mode argument is a numeric literal or data item with a PIC X USAGE COMP-X (or USAGE BINARY-CHAR) definition; it specifies how you wish to use the file, as follows:
The <var>angle</var> is assumed to be a value expressed in radians. If you need to determine the sine of an angle measured in degrees, you first need to convert that angle to radians as follows:
The <var>angle</var> is assumed to be a value expressed in radians. If you need to determine the tangent of an angle measured in degrees, you first need to convert that angle to radians as follows:
The byte-length argument may be a numeric literal or data item, and must be passed using BY VALUE (see CALL).
The byte-length argument may be a numeric literal or data item, and must be specified using BY VALUE (see CALL).
The <var>byte</var> data item need be only a single byte in size. If it is longer, the excess will be unaffected by this subroutine.
The class-name-1 option allows you to test for a user-defined class. Here’s an example. First, assume the following SPECIAL-NAMES (see SPECIAL-NAMES) definition of the user-defined class ‘
The computer-name, if specified, must immediately follow the OBJECT-COMPUTER paragraph name. The remaining clauses may be coded in any sequence.
The <var>conditional-expression-1</var> is evaluated. This comparison of the key(s) against the target literal/identifier values will have one of three possible outcomes:
The conditional-expression-1 should involve the KEY field(s), using the search index (the table’s INDEXED BY index name) as a subscript.
The <var>constant-name-1</var> name may not be referenced on a CDF directive.
The convert-length argument must be specified BY VALUE (see CALL). Any characters in data-item after the convert-length point will remain unchanged.
The convert-length argument must be specified BY VALUE (see CALL). It specifies how many (leading) characters in data-item will be converted — any characters after that will remain unchanged.
The <var>file-name-1</var> file
The file-name-1 file cannot be a sort/merge work file (a file described using a SD (see File/Sort-Description)).
The file-name-1 file must currently be open for INPUT (see File OPEN Modes) or I-O.

The file-name-1 value that you specify will be the name by which you will reference the file within your program. This name should be formed according to the rules for user-defined names (see User-Defined Words).
The <var>file-path</var> argument is an alphanumeric literal or data-item.

The format argument is a string (a group item, USAGE DISPLAY elementary item or an alphanumeric literal) documenting the format of time using hh, mm and ss to denote where the respective time information can be found. Any other characters found in format represent character positions that will be ignored. For example, a format of hhmmss indicates that time will be treated as a six-digit string value where the first two characters are the number of hours, the next two represent minutes and the last two represent seconds. A format of hh:mm:ss, however, describes time as an eight-character string where characters 3 and 6 will be ignored.
The <var>from-n</var> strings must match sequences in <var>string</var> exactly with regard to value and case.
The function-code argument must be either a numeric literal or a one-byte binary numeric data item (USAGE BINARY-CHAR is recommended).

The function-prototype-name-1 option is required to specify the name of a user-defined function your program will be using. Optionally, should you desire, you may specify an alias name by which you will reference that user-defined function. Should you wish, you may also use the AS clause to provide an alias name for a built-in intrinsic function.

The function argument must be a numeric literal or a 32-bit binary data item (USAGE BINARY-LONG, for example) with a value of 0 or 1. A value of 0 means that you will be registering (“installing”) an error procedure while a value of 1 indicates you’re de-registering (“uninstalling”) a previously-installed error procedure.

The function argument must be a numeric literal or a 32-bit binary data item (USAGE BINARY-LONG, for example) with a value of 0 or 1. A value of 0 means that you will be registering (“installing”) an exit procedure while a value of 1 indicates you’re deregistering (“uninstalling”) a previously-installed exit procedure.
The handle argument (PIC X(4) USAGE COMP-X) must have been populated by a prior call to CBL_OPEN_FILE built-in system subroutine (see CBL_OPEN_FILE).

The handle argument (PIC X(4) USAGE COMP-X) must have been populated by a prior call to CBL_OPEN_FILE. The offset argument (PIC X(4) USAGE COMP-X) defines the location in the file of the first byte to be written to. The first byte of a file is byte offset 0.
The <var>identifier-1</var> … field(s) must be defined as field(s) within a record of <var>sort-file-1</var>.

The <var>identifier-1</var> and <var>identifier-2</var> data items, along with all data items defined between those two data items in the program source, must all be contained within the same 01-level record description.
The identifier-1 data item should be defined as a USAGE BINARY-LONG data item.

The identifier-3) is neither automatically initialized (to spaces or any other value) at the start of a STRING statement nor will it be space-filled should the total number of sending item characters copied into it be less than its size. You may explicitly initialize identifier-3 yourself via the INITIALIZE (see INITIALIZE) or MOVE (see MOVE) statements before executing the STRING if you wish.
The imperative-statement-1 (see Imperative Statement) immediately following the ’

The imperative-statement-n (see Imperative Statement) specified on the WHEN clause whose conditional-expression-n evaluated to TRUE will be executed; after that, the search will be considered complete and control will fall into the first executable statement following the SEARCH.
The <var>item-1</var> argument must be a data item. The length of <var>item-1</var> must be at least 8*<var>byte-length</var>.
The length argument must be specified BY VALUE. The buffer argument must be specified BY REFERENCE.

The literal-1 or identifier-1 value specified must name a primary entry-point name (PROGRAM-ID of a subroutine or FUNCTION-ID of a user-defined function) or an alternate entry-point defined via an ENTRY statement within a subprogram.

The literal-1 value will specify the entry-point name of the subroutine. It must be specified exactly on CALL statements (with regard to the use of upper- and lower-case letters) as it is specified on the ENTRY statement.

The literal-3 clause displays the specified text on the SYSOUT/STDOUT device, waits for the user to press the Enter key and then — once the key has been pressed — allows the program to continue execution.

The literal-3 or identifier-4 value, if specified, must be a four- or six-digit value with the 1st half of the number indicating the line where the cursor should be positioned and the second half indicating the column. You may code only one of each clause on any ACCEPT.

The literal-n values are either integers or alphanumeric quoted characters. These represent a single character in the NATIVE character set, either by its actual text value (alphanumeric quoted character) or by ordinal position in the NATIVE character set (integer),
The mnemonic-name-1 / STATIC / STDCALL option, if used, affects the linkage conventions that will be used to the subroutine being called, as follows:
The <var>nanoseconds-to-sleep</var> argument is a numeric literal or data item.

The nbytes argument (PIC X(4) USAGE COMP-X) specifies how many bytes (maximum) will be read. If the flag argument is specified as 128, the size of the file (in bytes) will be returned into the file offset argument (argument 2) upon completion. Not all operating system/GnuCOBOL environments may be able to retrieve file sizes in such cases, a value of zero will be returned. The only other valid value for flags is 0. This argument may be specified either as a numeric literal or as a PIC X USAGE COMP-X data item.
The nbytes argument (PIC X(4) USAGE COMP-X) specifies how many bytes (maximum) will be written.
The offset argument (PIC X(8) USAGE COMP-X) defines the location in the file of the first byte to be read. The first byte of a file is byte offset 0.

The program-pointer must be a data item with a USAGE (see USAGE) of PROGRAM-POINTER containing the address of your error procedure. This item should be given a value using the SET Program-Pointer statement (see SET Program-Pointer). If the error procedure is written in GnuCOBOL, it must be a subroutine, not a user-defined function.
The program-pointer must be a data item with a USAGE (see USAGE) of PROGRAM-POINTER containing the address of your exit procedure.

The record-name-1 specified on the statement must be defined as an 01-level record subordinate to the File Description (FD (see File/Sort-Description)) of a file that is currently open for I-O (see File OPEN Modes).

The record-name-1 specified on the statement must be defined as an 01-level record subordinate to the File Description (FD (see File/Sort-Description)) of a file that is currently open for OUTPUT (see File OPEN Modes), EXTEND or I-O.
The return-code argument must be a one-byte binary numeric data item (USAGE BINARY-CHAR is recommended). It will receive a value of 0 if the operation was successful, 1 otherwise.

The seed may be any form of literal or data item. If seed is numeric, its numeric value will serve as the seed value. If seed is alphanumeric, a value for it will be determined as if it were used as an argument to NUMVAL (see NUMVAL).
The sort-file-1 named on the MERGE statement must be defined using a sort description (SD (see File/Sort-Description)). This file is referred to in the remainder of this discussion as the
The sort-file-1 named on the SORT statement must be defined using a sort description (SD (see File/Sort-Description)). This file is referred to in the remainder of this discussion as the
The sort-file-name-1 file must be a sort- or merge work file defined with a SD (see File/Sort-Description), not an FD.

The <var>start</var> value indicates the starting character position being referenced (character position values start with 1, not 0 as is the case in some programming languages) and <var>length</var> specifies how many characters are wanted.
The <var>string</var> must have any of the following formats, where ’#’ represents a sequence of one or more decimal digits:
The <var>table-name-1</var> data item must be a table defined in any data division section
The <var>table</var> data item must be at least 8 bytes long. If it is longer, the excess will be ignored by this subroutine.
The time string must contain hours, minutes and seconds. The time argument may be specified as a group item, USAGE DISPLAY elementary item or an alphanumeric literal.
The variable-arg argument should be an OCCURS 8 TIMES table of USAGE BINARY-CHAR.

The CDF text manipulation statements COPY and REPLACE are used to introduce new code into programs either with or without changes, or may be used to modify existing statements already in the program. Text manipulation statements are always terminated with a period.

The CDF text manipulation statementsCOPYandREPLACEare used to introduce new code into programs either with or without changes, or may be used to modify existing statements already in the program. Text manipulation statements are always terminated with a period.
trans-unit.target: Las declaraciones de manipulación de texto CDF COPY y REPLACE se utilizan para introducir código nuevo en programas con o sin cambios, o se pueden utilizar para modificar declaraciones existentes que ya están en el programa. Las declaraciones de manipulación de texto siempre terminan con un punto.

trans-unit.source: The COBOL 1985 standard introduced the concept of a reference modifier to facilitate references to only a portion of a data item; GnuCOBOL fully supports reference modification.

The COBOL language includes a powerful SORT statement that can sort large amounts of data according to arbitrarily complex key structures. This data may originate from within the program or may be contained in one or more external files. The sorted data may be written automatically to one or more output files or may be processed, record-by-record in the sorted sequence.

The COBOL2002 standard formalizes extensions to the COBOL language that allow for the definition and processing of text-based screens, as is a typical function on mainframe and midframe computers as well as on many point-of-sale (i.e. “cash register”) systems. GnuCOBOL implements virtually all the screen-handling features described by COBOL2002.

The COBOL2002 standard has made a common extension to the COBOL language — the GOBACK statement (see GOBACK) — a standard language element; the GOBACK statement should be strongly considered as the preferred alternative to both EXIT PROGRAM and EXIT FUNCTION for new subprograms.

The COBOL2002 standard has made a common extension to the COBOL language — theGOBACKstatement (see GOBACK) — a standard language element; theGOBACKstatement should be strongly considered as the preferred alternative to bothEXIT PROGRAMandEXIT FUNCTIONfor new subprograms.
trans-unit.target: El estándar COBOL2002 ha hecho una extensión común del lenguaje COBOL - la declaración GOBACK (ver GOBACK ) - un elemento de lenguaje estándar; la declaración GOBACK debe considerarse seriamente como la alternativa preferida a EXIT PROGRAM y EXIT FUNCTION para nuevos subprogramas.

trans-unit.source: The COBOL2002 standard, and therefore GnuCOBOL, only covers textual user interface (TUI) screens (those comprised of ASCII characters presented using a variety of visual attributes) and not the more-advanced graphical user interface (GUI) screen design and processing capabilities built into most modern operating systems. There are subroutine-based packages available that can do full GUI presentation — most of which may be called by GnuCOBOL programs, with a moderate research time investment (Tcl/Tk, for example) — but none are currently included with GnuCOBOL.
trans-unit.target: El estándar COBOL2002, y por lo tanto GnuCOBOL, solo cubre las pantallas de interfaz de usuario textual (TUI) (aquellas compuestas por caracteres ASCII presentados usando una variedad de atributos visuales) y no las capacidades de procesamiento y diseño de pantalla de interfaz gráfica de usuario (GUI) más avanzadas integradas en la mayoría de los sistemas operativos modernos. Hay paquetes disponibles basados ​​en subrutinas que pueden hacer una presentación GUI completa, la mayoría de los cuales pueden ser llamados por programas GnuCOBOL, con una inversión de tiempo de investigación moderada (Tcl / Tk, por ejemplo), pero ninguno se incluye actualmente con GnuCOBOL.

trans-unit.source: The Compiler Directing Facility, or CDF, is a means of controlling the compilation of GnuCOBOL programs. CDF provides a mechanism for dynamically setting or resetting certain compiler switches, introducing new source code from one or more source code libraries, making dynamic source code modifications and conditionally processing or ignoring source statements altogether. This is accomplished via a series of special CDF statements and directives that will appear in the program source code.

The GnuCOBOL implementation of RWCS does not issue any carriage-control information to the report files it produces — instead, it relies upon the information coded in the RD for the report (specifically the PAGE LIMITS and related options) and its internally-generated and managed LINE-COUNTER special register (see Special Registers) for the report to know when to issue any blank lines to the file to fill-out the end of a printed page.

The GnuCOBOL implementation of RWCS does not issue any carriage-control information to the report files it produces — instead, it relies upon the information coded in theRDfor the report (specifically thePAGE LIMITSand related options) and it’s internally-generated and managedLINE-COUNTERspecial register (see Special Registers) for the report to know when to issue any blank lines to the file to fill-out the end of a printed page.
trans-unit.target: La implementación de GnuCOBOL de RWCS no emite ninguna información de control de transporte a los archivos de informe que produce; en cambio, se basa en la información codificada en el RD para el informe (específicamente los PAGE LIMITS y opciones relacionadas) y se genera y administra internamente Registro especial LINE-COUNTER (ver Registros Especiales ) para que el informe sepa cuándo emitir líneas en blanco al archivo para completar el final de una página impresa.

trans-unit.source: The MinGW approach is a personal favourite with the author of this manual because it creates a GnuCOBOL compiler and runtime library that require only a single MinGW DLL to be available for the GnuCOBOL compiler, runtime library and user programs. That DLL is freely distributable under the terms of the GNU General Public License. A MinGW build of GnuCOBOL fits easily on and runs from a 128MB flash drive with no need to install any software onto the Windows computer that will be using it. Some functionality of the language, dealing with the sharing of files between concurrently executing GnuCOBOL programs and record locking on certain types of files, is sacrificed however as the underlying operating system routines needed to implement them aren’t available to Windows and aren’t provided by MinGW. The current version for MinGW is available at the download link along with various other platforms at the GnuCOBOL download website.

The MinGW approach is a personal favourite with the author of this manual because it creates a GnuCOBOL compiler and runtime library that require only a single MinGW DLL to be available for the GnuCOBOL compiler, runtime library and user programs. That DLL is freely distributable under the terms of the GNU General Public License. A MinGW build of GnuCOBOL fits easily on and runs from a 128MB flash drive with no need to install any software onto the Windows computer that will be using it. Some functionality of the language, dealing with the sharing of files between concurrently executing GnuCOBOL programs and record locking on certain types of files, is sacrificed however as the underlying operating system routines needed to implement them aren’t available to Windows and aren’t provided by MinGW. The current version for MinGW is available at the download link along with various other platforms at the GnuCobol download website (https://sourceforge.net/projects/open-cobol/files/gnu-cobol/2.0/).
trans-unit.target: El enfoque MinGW es uno de los favoritos personales del autor de este manual porque crea un compilador GnuCOBOL y una biblioteca en tiempo de ejecución que solo requiere que una sola DLL MinGW esté disponible para el compilador GnuCOBOL, la biblioteca en tiempo de ejecución y los programas de usuario. Esa DLL se puede distribuir libremente según los términos de la Licencia Pública General GNU. Una compilación MinGW de GnuCOBOL se adapta fácilmente y se ejecuta desde una unidad flash de 128 MB sin necesidad de instalar ningún software en la computadora con Windows que la utilizará. Sin embargo, se sacrifica parte de la funcionalidad del lenguaje, que se ocupa del intercambio de archivos entre la ejecución simultánea de programas GnuCOBOL y el bloqueo de registros en ciertos tipos de archivos, ya que las rutinas del sistema operativo subyacente necesarias para implementarlos no están disponibles para Windows y no se proporcionan por MinGW.La versión actual de MinGW está disponible en el enlace de descarga junto con otras plataformas en el sitio web de descarga de GnuCobol (https://sourceforge.net/projects/open-cobol/files/gnu-cobol/2.0/).

The RETURNING clause on the PROCEDURE DIVISION header documents that the subprogram in which the clause appears will be returning a numeric value back to the program that called it.

The SIZE phrase specifies the size (length) of the field. After the ACCEPT or DISPLAY is finished, the cursor is placed immediately after the field defined by this clause, unless this would place the cursor outside of the current terminal window. In this case, the cursor is wrapped around to the beginning of the next line (scrolling the window if necessary).

trans-unit.source: The actual key pressed to generate a function key (Fn) will depend on the type of terminal device you’re using (PC, Macintosh, VT100, etc.) and what type of enhanced display driver was configured with the version of GnuCOBOL you’re using.

The actual key pressed to generate a function key (Fn) will depend on the type of terminal device you’re using (PC, Macintosh, VT100, etc.) and what type of enhanced display driver was configured with the version of GnuCOBOL you’re using. For example, on a GnuCOBOL build for a Windows PC using MinGW and PDCurses, F1-F12 are the actual F-keys on the PC keyboard, F13-F24 are entered by shifting the F-keys, F25-F36 are entered by holding Ctrl while pressing an F-key and F37-F48 are entered by holding Alt while pressing an F-key. On the other hand, a GnuCOBOL implementation built for Windows using Cygwin and NCurses treats the PCs F1-F12 keys as the actual F1-F12, while shifted F-keys will enter F11-F20. With Cygwin/NCurses, Ctrl- and Alt-modified F-keys aren’t recognized. Neither are Shift-F11 or Shift-F12.
trans-unit.target: La tecla real presionada para generar una tecla de función (Fn) dependerá del tipo de dispositivo terminal que esté utilizando (PC, Macintosh, VT100, etc.) y qué tipo de controlador de pantalla mejorado se configuró con la versión de GnuCOBOL que usted ' estás usando. Por ejemplo, en una compilación de GnuCOBOL para una PC con Windows usando MinGW y PDCurses, F1-F12 son las teclas F reales en el teclado de la PC, F13-F24 se ingresan al mover las teclas F, F25-F36 se ingresan presionando Ctrl mientras presiona una tecla F y F37-F48 se ingresan manteniendo presionada la tecla Alt mientras presiona una tecla F. Por otro lado, una implementación de GnuCOBOL construida para Windows usando Cygwin y NCurses trata las teclas F1-F12 de la PC como la F1-F12 real, mientras que las teclas F cambiadas ingresarán F11-F20. Con Cygwin / NCurses, las teclas F modificadas con Ctrl y Alt no se reconocen. Tampoco lo son Shift-F11 o Shift-F12.

trans-unit.source: The alternative to using multiple entry points in your subroutine, by the way, would be to include an additional argument to the primary (and only) entry point of the subroutine; this new argument might be named STUDENT-FUNCTION and might have values of ‘

The alternative to using multiple entry points in your subroutine, by the way, would be to include an additional argument to the primary (and only) entry point of the subroutine; this new argument might be namedSTUDENT-FUNCTIONand might have values of "FETCH", "ADD", "UPDATE" or "DELETE".
trans-unit.target: La alternativa a utilizar múltiples puntos de entrada en su subrutina, por cierto, sería incluir un argumento adicional al punto de entrada principal (y único) de la subrutina; este nuevo argumento podría llamarse STUDENT-FUNCTION y podría tener valores de "FETCH", "ADD", "UPDATE" o "DELETE".

trans-unit.source: The amount of programming necessary to accomplish a given task — including rework needed by any errors found during testing (testing is sometimes jokingly defined as:

The amount of programming necessary to accomplish a given task — including rework needed by any errors found during testing (testing is sometimes jokingly defined as: "that time during which an application is actually in production, allowing users to discover the problems") is the measure of programmer productivity. Anything that reduces that effort will therefore reduce the time spent in such activities therefore reducing the expense of same. When the expense of programming is reduced, programmer productivity is increased.
trans-unit.target: La cantidad de programación necesaria para realizar una tarea determinada, incluida la repetición necesaria por cualquier error encontrado durante la prueba (la prueba a veces se define en broma como: "el tiempo durante el cual una aplicación está realmente en producción, lo que permite a los usuarios descubrir los problemas") es la medida de la productividad del programador. Cualquier cosa que reduzca ese esfuerzo reducirá, por tanto, el tiempo dedicado a dichas actividades, reduciendo así el gasto de las mismas. Cuando se reduce el gasto de programación, aumenta la productividad del programador.

If that won’t be necessary, "cob_init(0,NULL);" could be specified instead.

Si eso no es necesario, "cob_init (0, NULL);" podría especificarse en su lugar.

The capability exists for an additional field to be defined as what is known as an alternate key. Alternate key fields behave just like primary keys, allowing both direct and sequential access to record data based upon the alternate key field values, with one exception. That exception is the fact that alternate keys may be allowed to have duplicate values, depending upon how the alternate key field is described to the GnuCOBOL compiler.
trans-unit.target: Existe la capacidad de definir un campo adicional como lo que se conoce como clave alternativa.Los campos de claves alternativas se comportan igual que las claves primarias,permitiendo tanto el acceso directo como el secuencial a los datos de registro basados en los valores de los campos de claves alternativas,con una excepción.Esa excepción es el hecho de que se puede permitir que las claves alternativas tengan valores duplicados,dependiendo de cómo se describa el campo de clave alternativa al compilador GnuCOBOL.

If control reaches a NEXT SENTENCE clause due to the truth or falsehood of conditional-expression, control will be transferred to the first statement of the next sentence found in the program (the first statement after the next period).

trans-unit.source: The development of so-called "higher-level" programming languages that enable a programmer to specify in a single statement of the language an action that would have required many more separate statements in a prior programming language. The standardization of such languages, making them usable on a wide variety of computers and operating systems, was a key aspect of this development. COBOL was a pioneering development in this area, being a direct descendant of the very first higher-level language (FLOW-MATIC, developed by US Naval Lieutenant Grace Hopper) and the first to become standardized.
trans-unit.target: El desarrollo de los llamados lenguajes de programación de "nivel superior" que permiten a un programador especificar en una sola declaración del lenguaje una acción que habría requerido muchas más declaraciones separadas en un lenguaje de programación anterior.La normalización de esos lenguajes,que los hace utilizables en una amplia variedad de computadoras y sistemas operativos,fue un aspecto clave de este desarrollo.El COBOL fue un desarrollo pionero en esta área,siendo un descendiente directo del primer lenguaje de nivel superior (FLOW-MATIC,desarrollado por la teniente naval de los EE.UU.Grace Hopper)y el primero en ser estandarizado.

trans-unit.source: The effect of this statement will be to cause the specified files to share the same I/O buffer in memory. These buffers can sometimes get quite large, and by having multiple files share the same buffer memory you may significantly cut down the amount of memory the program is using (thus making "room" for more procedural code or data). If you do use this feature, take care to ensure that no more than one of the specified files are ever OPEN simultaneously.
trans-unit.target: El efecto de esta declaración será hacer que los archivos especificados compartan el mismo búfer de E/S en la memoria.Estos búferes a veces pueden llegar a ser bastante grandes,y al hacer que varios archivos compartan la misma memoria de búfer puede reducir significativamente la cantidad de memoria que el programa está utilizando (haciendo así "espacio" para más código o datos de procedimiento).Si utiliza esta función,asegúrese de que nunca se abra simultáneamente más de uno de los archivos especificados.

If you do use this feature, take care to ensure that no more than one of the specified files are ever OPEN simultaneously.

The effect of this statement will be to sort all transactions into ascending order of the date the transaction took place (oldest first, newest last). Unless the business running this program is going out of business, there are most-likely many transactions for any given date. Therefore, within each grouping of transactions all with the same date, transactions will be sub-sorted into ascending sequence of the account number the transactions apply to. Since it’s quite possible there might be multiple transactions for an account on any given date, a third level sub-sort will arrange all transactions for the same account on the same date into descending sequence of the actual amount of the transaction (largest first, smallest last). If two or more transactions of $100.00 were recorded for account #12345 on the 31<sup>st</sup> of August 2009, those transactions will be retained in the order in which they were loaded into the sort work file.

The effect of this statement will be to sort all transactions into ascending order of the date the transaction took place (oldest first, newest last). Unless the business running this program is going out of business, there are most-likely many transactions for any given date. Therefore, within each grouping of transactions all with the same date, transactions will be sub-sorted into ascending sequence of the account number the transactions apply to. Since it’s quite possible there might be multiple transactions for an account on any given date, a third level sub-sort will arrange all transactions for the same account on the same date into descending sequence of the actual amount of the transaction (largest first, smallest last). If two or more transactions of $100.00 were recorded for account #12345 on the 31st of August 2009, those transactions will be retained in the order in which they were loaded into the sort work file.
trans-unit.target: El efecto de esta declaración será ordenar todas las transacciones en orden ascendente de la fecha en que se realizó la transacción (la más antigua primero, la más reciente la última). A menos que la empresa que administra este programa vaya a cerrar, lo más probable es que haya muchas transacciones para una fecha determinada. Por lo tanto, dentro de cada grupo de transacciones, todas con la misma fecha, las transacciones se clasificarán en una secuencia ascendente del número de cuenta al que se aplican las transacciones. Dado que es muy posible que haya múltiples transacciones para una cuenta en una fecha determinada, una subclasificación de tercer nivel organizará todas las transacciones para la misma cuenta en la misma fecha en una secuencia descendente del monto real de la transacción (la más grande primero, la más pequeña último). Si se registraron dos o más transacciones de $ 100.00 para la cuenta # 12345 el 31 de agosto de 2009,esas transacciones se conservarán en el orden en que se cargaron en el archivo de trabajo de clasificación.

The establishment of programming techniques AND the introduction of programming language capabilities to facilitate the re-usability of program code. Anything that supports code re-usability can have a profound impact to the amount of time it takes to develop new applications or to make significant changes to existing ones. In recent years, object-oriented programming (OOP) has been the industry "poster child" for code re-usability. By enabling program logic and the data structures that logic manipulates to be encapsulated into easily stored and retrieved (and therefore "reusable") modules called classes, the object-oriented languages such as Java, C++ and C# have become the favourites of academia. Since students are being trained in these languages and only these, by and large, it’s no surprise that — today — object-oriented programming languages are the darlings of the industry.
trans-unit.target: El establecimiento de técnicas de programación Y la introducción de capacidades de lenguaje de programación para facilitar la reutilización del código del programa. Todo lo que admita la reutilización del código puede tener un impacto profundo en la cantidad de tiempo que lleva desarrollar nuevas aplicaciones o realizar cambios significativos en las existentes. En los últimos años, la programación orientada a objetos (OOP) ha sido el "niño del cartel" de la industria para la reutilización del código. Al permitir que la lógica del programa y las estructuras de datos que manipula la lógica se encapsulen en módulos fácilmente almacenados y recuperados (y por lo tanto "reutilizables") llamados clases, los lenguajes orientados a objetos como Java, C ++ y C # se han convertido en los favoritos del mundo académico. Dado que los estudiantes están siendo capacitados en estos idiomas y solo estos, en general,No es de extrañar que, hoy en día, los lenguajes de programación orientados a objetos sean los favoritos de la industria.

trans-unit.source: The establishment of programming techniques AND the introduction of programming language capabilities to facilitate the re-usability of program code. Anything that supports code re-usability can have a profound impact to the amount of time it takes to develop new applications or to make significant changes to existing ones. In recent years, object-oriented programming (OOP) has been the industry “poster child” for code re-usability. By enabling program logic and the data structures that logic manipulates to be encapsulated into easily stored and retrieved (and therefore “reusable”) modules called classes, the object-oriented languages such as Java, C++ and C# have become the favourites of academia. Since students are being trained in these languages and only these, by and large, it’s no surprise that — today — object-oriented programming languages are the darlings of the industry.

The establishment of programming techniques that make programs easier to read and therefore easier to understand. Not only do such techniques reduce the amount of rework necessary simply to make a program work as designed, but they also reduce the amount of time a programmer needs to study an existing program in order how to best adapt it to changing business requirements. The foremost development in this area was structured programming. Introduced in the late 1970’s, this approach to programming spawned new programming languages (PASCAL, ALGOL, PL/1 and so forth) designed around it. With the ANSI 85 standard, COBOL embraced the principles espoused by structured programming mavens as well as any of the languages designed strictly around it.
trans-unit.target: El establecimiento de técnicas de programación que faciliten la lectura de los programas y, por tanto, la comprensión. Estas técnicas no solo reducen la cantidad de reelaboración necesaria simplemente para que un programa funcione como se diseñó, sino que también reducen la cantidad de tiempo que un programador necesita para estudiar un programa existente a fin de adaptarlo mejor a los cambiantes requisitos comerciales. El principal avance en esta área fue la programación estructurada. Introducido a fines de la década de 1970, este enfoque de programación generó nuevos lenguajes de programación (PASCAL, ALGOL, PL / 1, etc.) diseñados en torno a él. Con el estándar ANSI 85, COBOL adoptó los principios propuestos por los expertos en programación estructurada, así como cualquiera de los lenguajes diseñados estrictamente en torno a él.

The expectation is that the subroutine will eventually return control back to the calling program, at which point the CALLing program will resume execution starting with the statement immediately following the CALL. Subprograms are not required to return to their callers, however, and are free to halt program execution if they wish.

trans-unit.target: La expectativa es que la subrutina eventualmente devolverá el control al programa que llama, momento en el cual el programa CALLing reanudará la ejecución comenzando con la declaración inmediatamente siguiente . Sin embargo, los subprogramas CALL no están obligados a regresar a sus llamadores y pueden detenerse ejecución del programa si lo desean.

trans-unit.source: The fact that GnuCOBOL supports a full-featured two-way interface with C-language programs means that — even if you cannot access a library API directly — you could always do so via a small C "wrapper" program that isCALLd by a GnuCOBOL program.
trans-unit.target: El hecho de que GnuCOBOL soporta una con todas las funciones de interfaz bidireccional con programas de lenguaje C significa que - incluso si no puede acceder a una biblioteca API directamente - siempre se puede hacerlo a través de una pequeña C "envoltorio" programa que es CALL d por una Programa GnuCOBOL.

trans-unit.source: The fact that GnuCOBOL supports a full-featured two-way interface with C-language programs means that — even if you cannot access a library API directly — you could always do so via a small C “wrapper” program that is CALLed by a GnuCOBOL program.

The final way in which a data item may be shared between a calling program (

The final way in which a data item may be shared between a calling program ("A") and a called program ("B") is by defining the data item (with the same name) in both programs and attaching theEXTERNAL(see EXTERNAL) clause to it (again, in both programs). This approach works regardless of whether the called program is nested within the calling program or not. It also works even if the two programs are compiled separately.
trans-unit.target: La última forma en que un elemento de datos puede ser compartido entre un programa de llamada ("A") y un programa llamado ("B") es definiendo el elemento de datos (con el mismo nombre) en ambos programas y adjuntando el EXTERNAL (ver EXTERNAL ) (nuevamente, en ambos programas). Este enfoque funciona independientemente de si el programa llamado está anidado dentro del programa de llamada o no. También funciona incluso si los dos programas se compilan por separado.

trans-unit.source: The first 16 characters returned by the CURRENT-DATE (see CURRENT-DATE) function will be a number in the format YYYYMMDDhhmmssnn, where YYYYMMDD is the current calendar date and hhmmssnn is the current time of day to the one one-hundredth of a second. Since two different executions of the program will never get identical CURRENT-DATE values (unless they are executed in extremely close time frames to one another), using those first sixteen characters as the RANDOM seed will guarantee that receiving a duplicate sequence of pseudo-random numbers in two different executions of the program will be

The first 16 characters returned by theCURRENT-DATE(see CURRENT-DATE) function will be a number in the format "YYYYMMDDhhmmssnn", where "YYYYMMDD" is the current calendar date and "hhmmssnn" is the current time of day to the one one-hundredth of a second. Since two different executions of the program will never get identicalCURRENT-DATEvalues (unless they are executed in extremely close time frames to one another), using those first sixteen characters as theRANDOMseed will guarantee that receiving a duplicate sequence of pseudo-random numbers in two different executions of the program will be HIGHLY unlikely.
trans-unit.target: Los primeros 16 caracteres devueltos por la función CURRENT-DATE (ver CURRENT-DATE ) serán un número en el formato "AAAAMMDDhhmmssnn", donde "AAAAMMDD" es la fecha actual del calendario y "hhmmssnn" es la hora actual del día. una centésima de segundo. Dado que dos ejecuciones diferentes del programa nunca obtendrán valores CURRENT-DATE idénticos (a menos que se ejecuten en marcos de tiempo extremadamente cercanos entre sí), el uso de esos primeros dieciséis caracteres como semilla RANDOM garantizará que la recepción de una secuencia duplicada de pseudoaleatorio los números en dos ejecuciones diferentes del programa serán MUY improbables.

trans-unit.source: The following are the fixed insertion editing symbols that may be specified in a picture string. Each of these editing symbols will insert a special character into the field value at the position it is specified in the picture string. These editing symbols will each introduce one extra character into the total field size for each occurrence of the symbol in the picture string.
trans-unit.target: Los siguientes son los símbolos de edición de inserción fija que se pueden especificar en una cadena de imágenes.Cada uno de estos símbolos de edición insertará un carácter especial en el valor del campo en la posición que se especifique en la cadena de imágenes.Cada uno de estos símbolos de edición introducirá un carácter adicional en el tamaño total del campo para cada ocurrencia del símbolo en la cadena de la imagen.

trans-unit.source: The following are the numeric formatting symbols that may be specified in a picture string. Each of these editing symbols will insert special characters into the field value to present numbers in a "friendly" format. These editing symbols will each introduce one extra character into the total field size for each occurrence of the symbol in the picture string. Numeric fields whose picture clause contains these characters may neither be used as source fields in any calculation nor may they serve as source fields for the transfer of data values to any data item other than an alphanumeric field.
trans-unit.target: A continuación se indican los símbolos de formato numérico que pueden especificarse en una cadena de imágenes.Cada uno de estos símbolos de edición insertará caracteres especiales en el valor del campo para presentar los números en un formato "amigable".Cada uno de estos símbolos de edición introducirá un carácter adicional en el tamaño total del campo por cada aparición del símbolo en la cadena de imágenes.Los campos numéricos cuya cláusula de imagen contenga estos caracteres no podrán utilizarse como campos fuente en ningún cálculo ni podrán servir como campos fuente para la transferencia de valores de datos a cualquier elemento de datos que no sea un campo alfanumérico.

trans-unit.source: The following program compares the performance of performing arithmetic operations (in a totally non-scientific, non-rigorous way) against data items with a USAGE (see USAGE) of DISPLAY, COMP and BINARY-LONG. It was actually my intent when I first wrote the program to merely demonstrate the relative performance differences between different types of numeric data storage, and it certainly met that objective.

The following program compares the performance of performing arithmetic operations (in a totally non-scientific, non-rigorous way) against data items with aUSAGE(see USAGE) ofDISPLAYCOMPandBINARY-LONG It was actually my intent when I first wrote the program to merely demonstrate the relative performance differences between different types of numeric data storage, and it certainly met that objective.
trans-unit.target: El siguiente programa compara el rendimiento de realizar operaciones aritméticas (de una manera totalmente no científica, no rigurosa) con elementos de datos con un USAGE (ver USO ) de DISPLAY COMP y BINARY-LONG .En realidad, era mi intención cuando escribí por primera vez el programa para demostrar simplemente las diferencias relativas de rendimiento entre los diferentes tipos de almacenamiento de datos numéricos, y ciertamente cumplió ese objetivo.

trans-unit.source: The idea is to pass two string and one full-word unsigned arguments to the subprogram, have the subprogram print them out, change all three and pass a return code of 2 back to the caller. The caller will then re-display the three arguments (showing changes only to the two BY REFERENCE arguments), display the return code and halt.

The idea is to pass two string and one full-word unsigned arguments to the subprogram, have the subprogram print them out, change all three and pass a return code of 2 back to the caller. The caller will then re-display the three arguments (showing changes only to the twoBY REFERENCEarguments), display the return code and halt.
trans-unit.target: La idea es pasar argumentos sin firmar de dos cadenas y una palabra completa al subprograma, hacer que el subprograma los imprima, cambiar los tres y pasar un código de retorno de 2 a la persona que llama. La persona que llama volverá a mostrar los tres argumentos (mostrando los cambios solo en los dos argumentos BY REFERENCE ), mostrará el código de retorno y se detendrá.

trans-unit.source: The identification division provides basic identification of the program by giving it a name and optionally defining some high-level characteristics via the eight pre-defined paragraphs that may be specified.
trans-unit.target: La división de identificación proporciona una identificación básica del programa dándole un nombre y,opcionalmente,definiendo algunas características de alto nivel a través de los ocho párrafos predefinidos que pueden especificarse.

trans-unit.source: The identifiers specified on the USING clause must be defined in the linkage section of the subprogram. No storage is actually allocated for those identifiers in the subprogram as the actual storage for them will exist in the calling program.

The identifiers specified on theUSINGclause must be defined in the linkage section of the subprogram. No storage is actually allocated for those identifiers in the subprogram as the actual storage for them will exist in the calling program.
trans-unit.target: Los identificadores especificados en la cláusula USING deben definirse en la sección de vínculos del subprograma. En realidad, no se asigna almacenamiento para esos identificadores en el subprograma, ya que el almacenamiento real para ellos existirá en el programa de llamada.

trans-unit.target: La condición de relación implícita <Selection-Subject> = <Selection Object> es VERDADERA. Consulte Condiciones de relación para conocer las reglas sobre cómo se realizará la comparación.

trans-unit.source: The included file NEWS will indicate when it is.

The indentation is purely at the discretion of the programmer to make things easier for humans to read (the compiler couldn’t care less). Historically, COBOL implementations that required Fixed Format Mode source programs required that the 01 level number begin in Area A and that everything else begins in Area B. GnuCOBOL only requires that all data definition syntax occur in columns 8-72. In Free Format Mode, of course, there aren’t even those limitations.

The indentation is purely at the discretion of the programmer to make things easier for humans to read (the compiler couldn’t care less). Historically, COBOL implementations that required Fixed Format Mode source programs required that the01level number begin in Area A and that everything else begins in Area B. GnuCOBOL only requires that all data definition syntax occur in columns 8-72. In Free Format Mode, of course, there aren’t even those limitations.
trans-unit.target: La sangría es puramente a discreción del programador para hacer las cosas más fáciles de leer para los humanos (al compilador no le importa). Históricamente, las implementaciones de COBOL que requerían programas fuente del Modo de formato fijo requerían que el número de nivel 01 comenzara en el Área A y que todo lo demás comience en el Área B. GnuCOBOL solo requiere que toda la sintaxis de definición de datos ocurra en las columnas 8-72. En el modo de formato libre, por supuesto, ni siquiera existen esas limitaciones.

trans-unit.source: The keyword LOCALE refers to the current locale (in effect at the time the program is executed)

trans-unit.source: The keywordUSER-DEFAULTreferences the default locale specified for the user currently executing this program.
trans-unit.target: La palabra clave USER-DEFAULT hace referencia a la configuración regional predeterminada especificada para el usuario que actualmente ejecuta este programa.

trans-unit.source: The line contains a valid GnuCOBOL statement that is normally treated as a comment unless the program is being compiled in debugging mode.
trans-unit.target: La línea contiene una declaración GnuCOBOL válida que normalmente se trata como un comentario a menos que el programa se esté compilando en modo de depuración.

trans-unit.source: The line is a comment that will also force a page eject in the compilation listing. While GnuCOBOL will honour such a line as a comment, it will not form-feed any generated listing.
trans-unit.target: La línea es un comentario que también forzará la expulsión de la página en el listado de compilación.Mientras que GnuCOBOL honrará tal línea como un comentario,no alimentará ningún listado generado.

trans-unit.source: The line is a comment.
trans-unit.target: La línea es un comentario.

trans-unit.source: The line is a continuation of the previous line. These are needed only when an alphanumeric literal (quoted character string), reserved word or user-defined word are being split across lines.
trans-unit.target: La línea es una continuación de la línea anterior.Sólo se necesitan cuando un literal alfanumérico (cadena de caracteres citados),una palabra reservada o una palabra definida por el usuario se dividen en líneas.

trans-unit.source: The line location of a report section or screen section field will be determined by the LINE (see LINE) clause.
The line location of a report section or screen section field will be determined by theLINE(see LINE) clause.
trans-unit.target: La ubicación de la línea de una sección de informe o de un campo de sección de pantalla estará determinada por la cláusula LINE (ver LINE ).

trans-unit.source: The linkage section describes data within a subprogram that serves as either input arguments to or output results from the subprogram.
The literal(s) specified on this clause define the possible characters that may be found in a data item’s value in order to be considered part of the class.
trans-unit.target: Los literales especificados en esta cláusula definen los posibles caracteres que se pueden encontrar en el valor de un elemento de datos para ser considerado parte de la clase.

trans-unit.source: The local-storage section is similar to working-storage, but describes data within a subprogram that will be dynamically allocated and initialized (automatically) each time the subprogram is executed. See Data Initialization, for the rules of data initialization.
The longoption structure is immutable! You can only vary the number of records.
The main program must be the first program found in the first compilation unit (

The main program must be the first program found in the first compilation unit ("mainprog.cbl"). The remainder of that compilation unit as well as the rest of the files in the compilation group ("sub1.cbl" and "sub2.cbl") must be independent and/or contained subprograms (see Independent vs Contained vs Nested Subprograms).
trans-unit.target: El programa principal debe ser el primer programa que se encuentre en la primera unidad de compilación ("mainprog.cbl"). El resto de esa unidad de compilación, así como el resto de los archivos del grupo de compilación ("sub1.cbl" y "sub2.cbl") deben ser subprogramas independientes y / o contenidos (consulte Subprogramas independientes frente a subprogramas contenidos frente a anidados ).

trans-unit.source: The management of paging, enforcement of the
The management of paging, enforcement of the "groups cannot span pages" rule and almost every aspect of report generation are handled entirely by the Report Writer Control System.
trans-unit.target: La gestión de la paginación,la aplicación de la regla de "los grupos no pueden traspasar las páginas" y casi todos los aspectos de la generación de informes son manejados en su totalidad por el Sistema de Control de Redacción de Informes.

trans-unit.source: The mandatory AT END clause is used to detect and react to the failure of an attempt to retrieve another record from the file due to an end-of-file (i.e. no more records) condition.
The mandatoryAT ENDclause is used to detect and react to the failure of an attempt to retrieve another record from the file due to an end-of-file (i.e. no more records) condition.
trans-unit.target: La cláusula obligatoria AT END se utiliza para detectar y reaccionar ante el fracaso de un intento de recuperar otro registro del archivo debido a una condición de fin de archivo (es decir, no hay más registros).

trans-unit.source: The manipulation of data files is one of the COBOL language’s great strengths. There are features built into COBOL to deal with the possibility that multiple programs may be attempting to access the same file concurrently. Multiple program concurrent access is dealt with in two ways — file sharing and record locking.

The manner in which the exit status value is interrogated by the operating system varies. Windows can use %ERRORLEVEL% to query the exit status while Unix shells such as sh, bash and ksh can query the exit status as $?. Other Unix shells may have different ways to access the exit status.

The meaning of REFERENCE, CONTENT and VALUE are the same as the equivalent specifications on the CALL statement (see CALL). Whatever specification will be used for an argument on the CALL to this entry-point should match the specification used in the corresponding ENTRY-Argument. The same rules regarding the presence or absence of a BY clause on a CALL statement apply to the presence or absence of a BY clause on the corresponding argument of the ENTRY statement.

The name COBOL actually says it all — COBOL is an acronym that stands for "(CO)mmon (B)usiness (O)riented (L)anguage". Note the fact that the word "common" comes before all others. The word "business" is a close second. Therein lies the key to Cobol’s success.
trans-unit.target: El nombre COBOL en realidad lo dice todo: COBOL es un acrónimo que significa "( CO ) mmon ( B ) usiness ( O ) riented ( L ) anguage". Tenga en cuenta el hecho de que la palabra "común" se antepone a todas las demás. La palabra "negocio" está en segundo lugar. Ahí radica la clave del éxito de Cobol.

trans-unit.source: The name COBOL actually says it all — COBOL is an acronym that stands for “(CO)mmon (B)usiness (O)riented (L)anguage”. Note the fact that the word “common” comes before all others. The word “business” is a close second. Therein lies the key to COBOL’s success.

The natural hierarchy of control breaks within a RWCS-controlled report based upon the manner in which the data the report is being generated from is sorted.
trans-unit.target: La jerarquía natural de control se rompe dentro de un informe controlado por el RWCS en función de la manera en que se clasifican los datos a partir de los cuales se genera el informe.

trans-unit.source: The net effect of the above algorithm is that only a fraction of the number of elements in the table need ever be tested in order to decide whether or not a particular entry exists. This is because the half the remaining entries in the table are discarded each time an entry is checked.
trans-unit.target: El efecto neto del algoritmo anterior es que sólo es necesario probar una fracción del número de elementos de la tabla para decidir si existe o no una entrada determinada.Esto se debe a que la mitad de las entradas restantes de la tabla se descartan cada vez que se comprueba una entrada.

trans-unit.source: The next (and last, in this case) break listed on the CONTROLS clause will be the one that occurs even more frequently (Sorted-Department-Number). The CONTROL FOOTING for this control field will be the one that summarizes sales for each department within a store.

trans-unit.source: The next break listed on the CONTROLS clause will be the one that occurs next most-frequently (Sorted-Store-Number). This control break will be the one that produces the summation for each entire store, and will have its own CONTROL FOOTING.

trans-unit.source: The only valid level numbers are 01-49, 66, 77, 78 and 88. Level numbers 01 through 49 are used to define data items that may be part of a hierarchical structure. Level number 01 can also be used to define a constant — an item with an unchangeable value specified at compilation time.
trans-unit.target: Los únicos números de nivel válidos son 01-49, 66, 77, 78 y 88. Los números de nivel 01 a 49 se utilizan para definir elementos de datos que pueden ser parte de una estructura jerárquica. El número de nivel 01 también se puede utilizar para definir una constante: un elemento con un valor inalterable especificado en el momento de la compilación.

trans-unit.source: The only valid level numbers are 01-49, 66, 77, 78 and 88. Level numbers 66, 77, 78 and 88 all have special uses — See Special Data Items, for details.
